description: A conditional statement that executes a block of code if a specified condition is true.
A loop that iterates over a sequence (like a list, tuple, or string) and executes a block of code for each item in the sequence.
A keyword used to define a function in Python.
A statement used to include the functionality of a module in the current script.
A blueprint for creating objects in object-oriented programming.
A statement used to exit a function and return a value to the caller.
A block of code that allows you to test a block of code for errors.
A block of code that handles exceptions raised in the try block.
A loop that continues to execute a block of code as long as a specified condition is true.
A statement used to wrap the execution of a block of code within methods defined by a context manager.
A small anonymous function defined with the lambda keyword.
A statement used in a function to return a generator.
A keyword used to declare that a variable inside a function is global (i.e., it exists in the global scope).
A keyword used to declare that a variable inside a nested function is not local to that function, but exists in the nearest enclosing scope.
A statement used to test if a condition is true, and if not, raise an AssertionError.
A statement used to exit a loop prematurely.
A statement used to skip the current iteration of a loop and continue with the next iteration.
A null statement that is used as a placeholder in code where a statement is syntactically required but no action is needed.
A statement used to delete objects in Python.
A statement used to raise an exception.
A comparison operator that checks if two variables point to the same object in memory.
A membership operator used to check if a value exists within an iterable (like a list, tuple, or string).
A logical operator used to invert the truth value of a condition.
